ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

COMMISSION OF INQUIRY
INTO
CONSTRUCTIONAL CAPACITY
OF SINGAPORE
(Employment of technical men to do administrative work)


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether, in the light of the finding of the Commission of Inquiry into the Constructional Capacity of Singapore that "the employment of technical men to do administrative work is a wasteful use of an extremely scarce resource", the Government would consider reorganisation of administrative work in all departments where technical and professional men discharge administrative functions.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission and with the agreement of the Member for Anson, I propose to table the answer.

    Copy of answer handed in.

    Mr Speaker: Of course, the formula would be that the Minister will publish the answer in the Official Report. He is entitled to do that even without asking for permission of the Member who asked the question.

    Following is the answer:

    (a) The quotation in the Interim Report of the Commission referred to by the Honour-able Member has specific reference to the circumstances existing in the P.W.D. and the City Engineer's Department. The Commission pointed out the adverse effect, from the point of administration, on the D.P.W. and his Deputy who are too involved with the daily routine administrative work of the department which could be equally well discharged by an Administrative Officer. In this connection, it was recommended that the former post of A.O. in the P.W.D. which was abolished in January, 1958, should be resuscitated. This recommendation of the Commission was accepted and the post of A.O. was created in January.

Column: 272



    (b) The Honourable Member has suggested the extension of this finding to the other departments in which technical and professional officers perform administrative functions. This is not a new idea and is an important factor to be considered in any organisation. The fact of the matter is that the Head or his Deputy Head of a technical department would have to discharge a certain amount of administrative work which cannot he delegated to any one. Further, at the present moment, experienced administrative officers are scarce, insufficient to man all the posts in the establishments of Government, it is always a problem of getting on with what you have and not with what you would want to have. In the case of certain Ministries, such as the Health and Education Ministries, which have a preponderant number of professional officers, some officers who show a flair for administrative work can be posted for administrative duties.

COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO CONSTRUCTIONAL CAPACITY
OF
SINGAPORE
(Interim and Final Reports)


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance, with regard to the Commission of Inquiry into the Constructional Capacity of Singapore, whether he would (a) explain why the Interim Report submitted by the Commission on 4th October, 1960, was only presented to the Assembly on 12th September, 1961; (b) state when is it anticipated that the final report would be received and presented; and (c) make a statement on the Interim Report indicating, inter alia, Government's policy as regards the reported acute shortages of staff.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: May I similarly ask permission to have the answer published in the Official Report?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Copy of answer handed in.

    Following is the answer:

    (a) The Commission, in their earls deliberations, realised the importance of the immediate problems relating to the capacity of the Government departments concerned with the Government's construction problem and to those departments whose functions and work affect construction activity and the utilization construction capacity, and decided to submit an Interim Report on the first 2 items of the

Column: 273

Terms of Reference. Briefly these are to enquire into the capacity of the building industry in Singapore and how it can be expanded.

    I agree that an early publication should have been given to the Interim Report but it was not possible to get this done owing to the other commitments, which are of a more urgent nature in some cases, of the Printing Department. But I may state that the recommendations have not, been delayed in implementation in any way through delay in printing. Before the publication of the Report, six of the major recommendations, including the one relating to the creation of the post of Administrative Officer in the P.W.D., were implemented; due publicity had been given to some of them.

    (b) The Final Report of the Commission of inquiry was submitted to His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara on the 16th June. Although the printing of the Report is in an advanced stage, I would not like to say when it will be presented to the Assembly. But it would not be long.

    (c) The existing shortage of technical officers is due largely to the retirement of experienced officers under the Malayanisation Scheme and partly to lack of fore-sight to fill this vacuum. This deficiency is accentuated in a way by the development of these technical services. Since the Government took office, it has realised the importance of an interim measure of overseas recruitment of these technical officers on a temporary basis to tide over this shortage and had carried out negotiations with a number of governments who are in a position to assist. The results have so far been meagre as technical personnel are in demand all over the world. In addition, the number of under-graduate and postgraduate scholarships in all branches of engineering, medicine, architecture, etc, have been greatly increased. It will be many years, however, before we reap the benefit.

CONTROL OF IMPORTS AND
EXPORTS (AMENDMENT) BILL
First Reading


2.33 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to amend the Control of Imports and Exports Ordinance (Chapter 214 of the Revised Edition)."

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

Column: 274



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Now, Sir. I lay upon the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in respect of the Control of Imports and Exports (Amendment) Bill, 1961.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are typed copies of the Bill available for the use of Members?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes.

    Typed copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker. Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill seeks to make the Control of Imports and Exports Ordinance a permanent Ordinance. The Ordinance was promulgated on 8th December, 1950, initially for one year. It has since been extended for ten further periods of a year each and will expire on 7th December, 1961.

    Although the Ordinance provides that the Assembly may extend its operation for such period or periods as it may think fit, in practice extensions have been for periods of one year. The Ordinance empowers the Minister to make orders to regulate or prohibit the import and export of goods. The reason why this Ordinance had such a temporary nature at the time it was introduced was due to the opposition from the trading community who feared that controls, if made permanent, would be detrimental to trade and Singapore's free port status.

    During the past ten years, most import and export regulations have been removed and those at present in being are imposed mainly for health, security and exchange control reasons. In present world conditions, the power to exercise controls on imports and exports is one maintained by all trading countries as being essential in a lesser or greater degree to the requirement of their economic policies concerning trade and industry. In the interest of the economy of the State of Singapore. it is necessary that the Government should have the powers to restrict or direct imports and exports as might be required.

Column: 275



    My Trade and Commerce Advisory Council, which is composed of representatives of the four Chambers of Commerce, has been consulted and has no objection to the proposal that the Ordinance be made a permanent one. As matters now stand, it is necessary to extend the life of the Ordinance from time to time. It is considered that this procedure takes up unduly the time of the House and that the basic reason for its temporary nature, namely, the fear of the trading community over controls, has now been allayed over these last ten years.

    For these reasons, it is proposed to make the Ordinance a permanent statute of the State, but in so moving, I wish to assure the House that as before the powers under the Ordinance will only be exercised after careful examination and with due consideration to the needs of Singapore's trade.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I acknowledge that the powers of this Ordinance have been exercised with moderation and for the welfare of the State. I fully appreciate the reasons which our Finance Minister has given for making it a permanent Ordinance and I am fully with him in every one of the reasons indicated. What I cannot understand, Sir, is that this Bill should be brought under a Certificate of Urgency. Our Standing Orders provide that a Certificate of Urgency may be utilised, and it has all along been envisaged that it could be utilised for matters of urgency which cannot await a lengthy debate or a postponement of a month. Here in this case the Minister must agree with me that there is, in so far as one can ascertain, no urgency of any character whatsoever. There is no question of the Bill lapsing in any shape or form. [Interruption]. It is to lapse shortly. Well, I am interested, Sir, to be corrected, perhaps not in a quite procedural manner. In that statement, the Minister did not see fit to tell us that the Bill was about to lapse; but if that

Column: 276

were so, would it not have been appropriate to bring this up at an earlier stage?

    I do urge the Government - we have had two Bills in this Session and in both there were Certificates of Urgency - that when it comes to exercising the very unusual powers in the Standing Orders, they should not utilise that power unless absolutely essential.

    Mr Speaker: Dr Goh, in reply?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps the Member for Anson did not hear the words in the beginning of my speech and I may be permitted to repeat that section of it. I said:

    `The Ordinance was promulgated on 8th December, 1950, initially for one year. It has since been extended for ten further periods of a year each and will expire on 7th December, 1961.'

That is the reason why this Bill must be taken through all stages under a Certificate of Urgency.

    We had, of course, originally intended that the Bill should he presented to the House some months ago but events have been such that it was not possible to place this Bill before the House then. Finally we are caught very short time and have to follow this procedure of urgency. I can assure the Member for Anson that there is no intention at all to pull a fast one either over this House or over the public.

    This is really not a controversial matter for reasons already stated. We have the assent of leaders of the trading community, and it is clear to both the Government and leaders of the trading community that the best course now open to us is to put this Bill on the permanent Statute.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Assembly immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill.- [ Dr Goh Keng Swee].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported, without amendment read a Third time and passed.

MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


    The Minister for Labour (Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim)(In Malay): Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise to move the motion+ in my name. The separation of Singapore from the Federation is a criminal act committed by the British colonialists in 1945 when the Federated Malay States and the Unfederated Malay States with the two Straits Settlements of Penang and Malacca were united as a Federation. At that time. Singapore was excluded from the Federation. All anti-colonialists did not cease to fight against the separation created by mankind. Sir, I intentionally used the word "anti-colonialists" because the nationalists and the Communists have both opposed colonialism and have fought against the separation.
+The motion reads as follows:

    That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya.

    Therefore, for the last 16 years, one of the slogans which was constantly heard in the nationalists' circle, including the Communists, was merger and the reunification of Singapore with the Federation. Therefore, Sir, it is no exaggeration if I move such a motion asking all Members of this House to support this merger in principle. We must presume that all Members of this House are nationalists. If they are not nationalists, then I feel that they will call themselves anti-colonialists and non-Communists. Whatever name they may call themselves, we do not ask them to say what is their stand, or whether they are in support of or that they oppose the principle of merger.

    As you know, only the Members of the Barisan Sosialis will be in an embarrassing position and will be in a predicament to support this merger in principle, and the principle of merger which is asked in this motion. To the members of the public, they say that they wish for merger more than anything else, anti more than anything else that has been fought for by the P.A.P. Government. Therefore, it will he strange if they vote against this motion. However, we know, anti they also know, that in their heart of hearts, merger is a matter which they do not wish, because merger means that the question of internal security will be placed in the hands of the Central Government of the Federation of Malaya, and that their hope to establish Singapore as an area separate from Malaya `will disappear. But that is their problem. To the public, they say they want merger more than the type of merger which the P.A.P. is asking for. But, in actual fact, they fear merger. We now ask them to say in this House whether they support or oppose this principle of merger. If they support merger, then we may be able to discuss the details which should be placed in the hands of the Central Government when merger is achieved. Thus, on the one hand, they oppose merger, but in public they are forced to support it. Then when we discuss the details concerning

    The words of this motion. Sir, convey high and noble sentiments to which none of us can disagree. But, Sir, the record of the Government in recent months has clearly shown that their actions do not in any way match these high-sounding words.
